sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• General anesthesia: induction, 1.5 to 3% isoflurane with oxygen or oxygen-nitrous oxide mixture
  • General anesthesia: maintenance, 1 to 2.5% with nitrous oxide, additional 0.5 to 1% with oxygen alone

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety in children under 2 yr of age has not been established
  • General anesthesia: dosage must be individualized

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: myasthenia gravis: greater sensitivity to neuromuscular effects, additional muscle relaxant may not be necessary

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to isoflurane or other halogenated agents,
  • malignant hyperthermia, known or suspected genetic susceptibility

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• CO(2) absorbents, desiccated, administration with; may form carbon monoxide, with potential increases in carboxyhemoglobin levels
  • concentration of isoflurane increasing during anesthesia; dose-related hypotension and respiratory depression, and increases in cerebral spinal fluid pressure have been reported
  • coronary artery disease; increased risk of myocardial ischemia
  • obstetrical anesthesia; increased blood loss has been reported during abortions
  • pediatric patients; potentially fatal hyperkalemia has been reported; risk increases with concomitant administration of succinylcholine, and in patients with latent or overt neuromuscular disease (especially Duchenne muscular dystrophy)
  • sensitivity to halogenated anesthetics, previous; sensitivity hepatitis has been reported

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Gastrointestinal:Nausea, Vomiting
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiac arrest, Myocardial infarction, Myocardial ischemia
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hyperkalemia, Malignant hyperthermia
  • Hepatic:Decreased liver function (rare), Hepatic necrosis, Liver failure
  • Neurologic:Seizure
  • Renal:Myoglobinuria, Renal failure
  • Respiratory:Respiratory depression

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Isoflurane is a general anesthetic agent capable of producing profound respiratory depression.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Inhalation
calibrated vaporizer or vaporizer with calculated flow required

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• induction of anesthesia
  • blood pressure
  • temperature and respiratory rate

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    • Inhalation Liquid: 99.9 %
    • Inhalation Solution: 99.9 %
  • Forane
    Inhalation Liquid: 99.9 %
  • Novaplus Terrell
    Inhalation Solution: 99.9 %
  • Terrell
    Inhalation Solution: 99.9 %

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
ISOFLURANE
OVERDOSE: Isoflurane overdose may result in hypotension, coma, respiratory depression, apnea, and seizures. ADVERSE EFFECTS: At normal anesthetic doses isoflurane has been associated with hypotension, dysrhythmias, seizures, nephrotoxicity, hepatotoxicity, malignant hyperthermia, and respiratory depression.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
ISOFLURANE
  • Decontamination: INHALATION - Administer high flow oxygen, establish airway and assist respirations as needed. INGESTION - Emesis is contraindicated due to rapid onset CNS depression. Absorption is rapid, gastric decontamination is unlikely to be useful unless performed very soon after ingestion. DERMAL - Remove contaminated clothing and wash exposed area extremely thoroughly with soap and water.
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates.
  • Malignant hyperthermia: Stop exposure immediately. Reduce body temperature with external cooling measures. Administration of dantrolene may be considered. DANTROLENE - Initial dose of 1 mg/kg rapid IV, may be repeated as needed to a cumulative dose of 10 mg/kg.
  • Conduction disorder of the heart: Lidocaine and amiodarone for stable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. Obtain an ECG, institute continuous cardiac monitoring and administer oxygen. Evaluate for hypoxia, acidosis, and electrolyte disorders (particularly hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia).
  • Airway management: Administer oxygen and endotracheally intubate as clinically indicated.
  • Acidosis: Treat acidosis (pH less than 7.1) with IV sodium bicarbonate.
  • Fluid/electrolyte balance regulation: Fluid and electrolyte replacement may be necessary in cases of metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and myoglobinemia.
  • Hypotensive episode: IV 0.9% NS, dopamine, norepinephrine.
  • Rhabdomyolysis: Early aggressive fluid replacement to prevent renal insufficiency. Diuretics may be needed to maintain urine output. Urinary alkalinization is NOT routinely recommended.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
ISOFLURANE
TOXICITY: The toxic dose has not been established. Ingestion of approximately 80 mL of isoflurane was fatal in an adult. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: ADULTS: General anesthesia induction, 1.5% to 3% isoflurane with oxygen or oxygen-nitrous oxide mixture. General anesthesia maintenance, 1% to 2.5% with nitrous oxide, additional 0.5% to 1% with oxygen alone
